The Agile approach is a departure from traditional, sequential development models, which attempt to follow a rigid plan from start to finish. Instead, Agile teams work in short, iterative cycles, called sprints, which typically last from one to four weeks. Each sprint involves planning a set of features or requirements to be developed, followed by the team working together to complete those tasks. At the end of each sprint, a usable product is delivered to the customer, and the team gathers feedback, which is then incorporated into the next sprint.

The Agile methodology is based on a set of values and principles, outlined in the Agile Manifesto. These values include individuals and interactions over processes and tools, working software over comprehensive documentation, customer collaboration over contract negotiation, and responding to changing requirements over following a plan.

Agile methodologies, such as Scrum or Extreme Programming (XP), provide specific frameworks and practices
